title: Measuring change in multidimensional poverty using structural equation modelling
abstractText:
Poverty is generally recognised to be relative and multidimensional in nature. However, traditional techniques for developing multidimensional measures of poverty tend to produce unstable results that prevent accurate monitoring of trends. Furthermore, such measures generally omit the psychosocial stress, social stigma and loss of dignity and autonomy (associated with low income) that are frequently emphasised by people who experience poverty.

Both problems are potentially solvable by the application Structural Equation Modelling (SEM). Analysis of the British Household Panel Survey will explore the potential of structural equation modelling to generate robust multi-dimensional measures of poverty. It will also seek to establish and explain trends in the incidence, pattern and duration of poverty in Britain, measured in this way, between 1991 and 2003.

The research, which will take 15 months to complete, will also provide a critique of traditional poverty measures.
